title: Pharmaceutical Drugs and Natural Therapeutic Products for the Treatment of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
author: Jana Blahova; Monika Martiniakova; Martina Babikova; Veronika Kovacova; Vladimira Mondockova; Radoslav Omelka; Blahova; Jana; Martiniakova; Monika; Babikova; Martina; Kovacova; Veronika; Mondockova; Vladimira; Omelka; Radoslav
description: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is the most widespread form of diabetes, characterized by chronic hyperglycaemia, insulin resistance, and inefficient insulin secretion and action. Primary care in T2DM is pharmacological, using drugs of several groups that include insulin sensitisers (e.g., biguanides, thiazolidinediones), insulin secretagogues (e.g., sulphonylureas, meglinides), alpha-glucosidase inhibitors, and the newest incretin-based therapies and sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors. However, their long-term application can cause many harmful side effects, emphasising the importance of the using natural therapeutic products. Natural health substances including non-flavonoid polyphenols (e.g., resveratrol, curcumin, tannins, and lignans), flavonoids (e.g., anthocyanins, epigallocatechin gallate, quercetin, naringin, rutin, and kaempferol), plant fruits, vegetables and other products (e.g., garlic, green tea, blackcurrant, rowanberry, bilberry, strawberry, cornelian cherry, olive oil, sesame oil, and carrot) may be a safer alternative to primary pharmacological therapy. They are recommended as food supplements to prevent and/or ameliorate T2DM-related complications. In the advanced stage of T2DM, the combination therapy of synthetic agents and natural compounds with synergistic interactions makes the treatment more efficient. In this review, both pharmaceutical drugs and selected natural products, as well as combination therapies, are characterized. Mechanisms of their action and possible negative side effects are also provided.
cleaned_text: Pharmaceutical Drugs and Natural Therapeutic Products for the Treatment of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus [https://doi.org/10.3390/ph14080806](https://doi.org/10.3390/ph14080806) [Multitarget Drug T2DM is a chronic endocrine disorder characterized by hyperglycaemia, insulin resistance, ineffective insulin secretion by the pancreas [ [2](#B2-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [3](#B3-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], and increased hepatic glucose production [ [4](#B4-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. These conditions manage lower glucose transport to the liver, muscle cells and fat cells [ [5](#B5-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. An important feature of diabetes is hyperlipidaemia, which results from the use of lipids instead of glucose [ [6](#B6-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [7](#B7-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Patients with T2DM are at a higher risk of microvascular complications (e.g., diabetic retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy) and macrovascular ones (such as cardiovascular disease, stroke, and peripheral artery disorder) than the non-diabetic population. Other clinical conditions associated with T2DM include diabetic foot and reduced resistance to various infections [ [8](#B8-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [9](#B9-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [10](#B10-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The clinical consequences of hyperglycaemia are polyuria, weight loss (sometimes with polyphagia), and blurred vision [ [11](#B11-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Renal impairment, impaired growth and development, lipodystrophy, non-alcoholic fatty liver damage, limited joint mobility, and oedema can also be diagnosed [ [10](#B10-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In addition, diabetic bone disease is reported as an important secondary complication of T2DM. This abnormality is manifested by altered bone mineral density (BMD), disorders of skeletal microarchitecture and bone metabolism, decreased bone strength, and the lower expression of genes associated with osteoblast function [ [12](#B12-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [13](#B13-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. As a result, almost all organ systems can be adversely affected by T2DM-related complications. Selected diabetic complications are illustrated in [Figure 1](#pharmaceuticals-14-00806-f001). 2. Molecular Mechanisms of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus [10](#B10-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [14](#B14-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Impaired -cell function leads to a decrease in glucose responsiveness [ [15](#B15-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] and its insufficient treatment reduces the number of pancreatic -cells and affects long-term blood glucose control [ [16](#B16-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Insulin doses are high during chronic hyperglycaemia and T2DM, leading to the exhaustion of -cells and deficiency in insulin biosynthesis and secretion [ [17](#B17-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Generally, insulin synthesis begins reticulum, where it is metabolized to proinsulin. Subsequently, proinsulin is transported to the Golgi apparatus, where insulin is formed [ [18](#B18-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The main stimulator of insulin secretion is elevated blood glucose level. Glucose enters the pancreatic -cells via a low-affinity glucose transporter (GLUT-2 in rodents, and GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 in humans), which is then phosphorylated. Pyruvate is then generated by glycolysis in the cytoplasm metabolized by pyruvate carboxylase and pyruvate dehydrogenase in mitochondria. This process the cytoplasmic adenosine triphosphate (ATP)/adenosine diphosphate (ADP) ratio, resulting in the closure of ATP-sensitive K+ channels. The closure of these channels is associated with another process that leads to activation of L-type voltage-dependent calcium (Ca2+) channels and ultimately to the release of insulin into the circulation [ [19](#B19-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. [Figure 2](#pharmaceuticals-14-00806-f002)shows the mechanism of insulin release by -cells. The regulation of insulin secretion is controlled by nutrients (e.g., glucose, free fatty acids), endocrine peptides, hormones (e.g., insulin, leptin, incretins, growth hormone, prolactin, glucagon), and the autonomic nervous system [ [20](#B20-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The molecular background of diabetic pancreatic -cell dysfunction is based on cellular stress in the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondrial dysfunction. These conditions are influenced by hyperglycaemia (glucotoxicity), hyperlipidaemia (lipotoxicity), and chronic inflammation. Inflammation is characterized by an imbalance between compensatory mechanisms and elevated levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines [ [17](#B17-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [21](#B21-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In the diabetic state, a defect in hepatic glucose production is recorded. Insulin action is generally reduced in the liver and peripheral tissues and causes elevated hepatic gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, decreased glucose uptake by peripheral tissues, and higher glucose levels in the blood [ [22](#B22-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. [16](#B16-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [23](#B23-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Factors that affect insulin resistance include age, exercise, diet, and body fat distribution [ [24](#B24-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. It occurs in peripheral tissues (especially in adipose, hepatic, and muscular tissues), and results in an increased amount of secreted insulin [ [10](#B10-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [25](#B25-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Generally, insulin receptors are part of the receptor family with tyrosine kinase activity. After insulin binds to its receptor, there are conformational changes of the receptor and autophosphorylation, and the activation of receptor's tyrosine kinases is observed. These changes lead to the tyrosine phosphorylation of insulin receptor substrates and Shc. IRSs are considered to be adapter molecules which organize the formation of molecular complexes and start cascades of intracellular signalling [ [25](#B25-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [26](#B26-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In general, insulin has two signalling pathways. The first is consistent with the activation of the phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K)/Akt pathway (also known as protein kinase B, PKB). PI3-K stimulation promotes increased nitric oxide (NO), Na+ pump, K+ channel, and Ca2+ myofilament This pathway activates insulin or insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). The second pathway acts through the mitogen-activated protein kinases/Ras pathway regulating gene expression and insulin-associated mitogenic effects [ [14](#B14-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [25](#B25-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In patients with T2DM, impaired insulin activation is the result of defects in the IRS-1/PI3K/Akt signalling pathway. These conditions have detrimental effects on insulin action and glucose metabolism. These defects may be partially resolved by treatment with insulin-sensitising agents and effective lifestyle changes [ [26](#B26-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. 3. Treatment of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus [27](#B27-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [28](#B28-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Supposedly, physical activity can reduce the risk of T2DM development by 30-50%, due to a lower incidence of obesity [ [3](#B3-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Physical activity contributes to enhanced insulin sensitivity in tissues, improves glucose and lipid levels, regulates blood pressure, and supports the cardiovascular system, which together lead to weight loss and a better quality of life [ [28](#B28-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Caloric intake and diet quality are also important in the management of T2DM. Dietary aspects can also influence blood glucose and lipid concentrations, blood pressure, body weight, and health conditions. Patients with T2DM should avoid smoking, alcohol consumption and limit sodium intake [ [3](#B3-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. It is strongly recommended that patients consume unsaturated fats and dietary meat with a low content of saturated and trans fats, foods with a low glycaemic index, sweeteners with a lower caloric value, fresh fruits, and vegetables. A high-fibre diet reduces the risk of cardiovascular diseases. The consumption of products rich in omega-3 fatty acids also reduces this risk [ [2](#B2-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [28](#B28-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [29](#B29-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Furthermore, the addition of minerals, especially chromium (Cr), magnesium (Mg), and vanadium (V) is very important. Chromium is a secondary messenger/cofactor of insulin that increases insulin sensitivity and the activity required for normal glucose and lipid metabolism. Magnesium is a mediator of insulin action and vanadium has insulin-like effects on the metabolism of glucose, enhances insulin action, and the sensitivity of its receptors [ [30](#B30-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [31](#B31-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [32](#B32-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. T2DM is strongly associated with oxidative stress, which is consistent with an increased prevalence of secondary diabetic complications. Various damages caused by oxidative stress can be limited by vitamins with antioxidant properties (e.g., vitamins C, E and A) [ [29](#B29-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [33](#B33-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Functional foods, for example whole-grain diet biscuits, whole-grain breakfast cereals, and bee products, can also eliminate diabetic problems [ [34](#B34-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. A higher intake of whole grains (unlike refined grain) lower the risk of T2DM mainly due to their high fibre content. Dietary fibres decrease starch accessibility to alpha-amylase and reduce glucose diffusion; stimulate satiety signals; and affect production of hormones involved in body weight regulation and energy homeostasis, as well as in glucose control [ [35](#B35-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Other bioactive compounds such as phenolic compounds, phytosterols, betaine, and carotenoids may also contribute to an improved insulin sensitivity by hampering oxidative stress, the transcription of inflammatory cytokines and chronic low-grade inflammation. In addition, vitamins (e.g., B and E) and minerals (e.g., Mg, zinc (Zn), and selenium (Se)) found in whole grains can reduce oxidative stress and inflammation [ [36](#B36-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Capcarova et al. [ [37](#B37-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] and Martiniakova et al. [ [38](#B38-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] state the protective impact of bee bread against hyperglycaemia, hyperlipidaemia, and diabetic bone disease in the appropriate T2DM animal model. Moreover, the most famous bee product, honey, can also improve glycaemic control and reduce secondary diabetic complications [ [39](#B39-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Honey is composed mostly of saccharides (mainly fructose) and water, but it also contains a wide range of nutrients including proteins, fatty acids, prebiotics, probiotics, fibre, phytochemicals, bioactive peptides, minerals (e.g., Zn, (Cu), and V), vitamins, organic acids, phenolic acids, flavonoids, and carotenoids [ [34](#B34-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Its hypoglycaemic properties are attributed to several mechanisms, the most important mechanism is based on fructose action. Fructose has lower glycaemic index when compared to glucose. Its mechanisms of action may include a reduced rate of intestinal absorption, the prolongation of gastric emptying time, and a reduced food intake. Fructose stimulates glucokinase and inhibits phosphorylase activity in the liver. The aforementioned minerals, phenolic acids, and flavonoids might also have a role in the hypoglycaemic process. In addition, honey has antioxidant properties and reduces oxidative stress in pancreatic -cells [ [40](#B40-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. However, the long-term application of pharmacological agents can be associated with many harmful side effects, emphasising the importance of natural therapeutic compounds. The acceptance and use of natural health products as alternative therapies is dramatically increasing because natural product-derived drugs are more affordable, with fewer side effects compared to conventional pharmaceutical therapies. In addition, the combination therapy of synthetic drugs and natural compounds has the potential to make the treatment more effective, especially in the advanced stage of T2DM [ [43](#B43-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Here, we introduce some pharmaceutical options, natural therapeutic products, selected plant fruits, vegetables, and other products useful in the treatment of T2DM. 3.1. Pharmaceutical Drugs for the Treatment of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus [41](#B41-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [44](#B44-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. However, the efficacy of drugs for weight loss varies and can range from mild weight loss (less than 3.2% of the initial weight) to strong weight loss (greater than 5% of the initial weight) [ [45](#B45-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Besides, none of these synthetic drugs are free from adverse effects. These include hypoglycaemia, lactic acidosis, gastrointestinal disorders, weight gain, renal failure, and etc. According to Raptis and Dimitriadis [ [46](#B46-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], Drucker et al. [ [47](#B47-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] and Nathan et al. [ [48](#B48-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], antidiabetic drugs can be divided into the following categories: insulin sensitisers (e.g., biguanides and thiazolidinediones), receptor dipeptyl peptidase-4 inhibitors). Other groups represent the sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors (decreased hyperglycaemia by enhanced [48](#B48-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. 3.1.1. Insulin Sensitisers [50](#B50-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Pharmaceutical drugs that include biguanides and thiazolidinediones. Biguanides [51](#B51-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [52](#B52-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The source of metformin is galegine, a natural product produced by the plant Galega officinalis [ [53](#B53-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [54](#B54-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The impact of metformin is associated with decreased hepatic glucose production, increased insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues, and reduced insulin levels during fasting. The downregulation of hepatic glucose production occurs via AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK), which promotes mitochondrial activity in cells. The mitochondrial control of hepatic gluconeogenesis leads to lower cellular energy and gluconeogenesis. Supposedly, insulin resistance may be improved through the beneficial effects of metformin on the expression of the insulin receptor and the activity of tyrosine kinase. Another mechanism includes an enhanced expression of the incretin receptor gene through the action of glucagon-like peptide 1, leading to the stimulation of -cells [ [22](#B22-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [54](#B54-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [55](#B55-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Moreover, metformin positively affects diabetic bone structure through increased osteoblast proliferation, type I collagen production and alkaline phosphatase activity [ [56](#B56-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [57](#B57-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Metformin treatment can be consistent with the elevated possibility of lactic acidosis (characterized by excessively low pH in the bloodstream), as well as with gastrointestinal adverse effects (diarrhoea and nausea being the most common) [ [58](#B58-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [59](#B59-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [60](#B60-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Thiazolidinediones [61](#B61-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [62](#B62-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The application of thiazolidinediones leads to a reduction of blood glucose levels, an improvement in -cells function [ [61](#B61-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], and a decrease in insulin resistance (especially in adipose and liver tissues) [ [63](#B63-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Their application is also associated with lower levels of circulating free fatty acids [ [61](#B61-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], anti-inflammatory effects [ [64](#B64-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], and reduced risk of cardiovascular diseases [ [65](#B65-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. These improvements are caused by the activation of the nuclear transcription factor PPAR [ [63](#B63-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], which is primarily found in adipose tissue, and is involved in glucose, lipid and protein metabolisms. Generally, thiazolidinediones have a high affinity to the PPAR receptor [ [66](#B66-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The PPAR agonists increase the expression and secretion of the hormone adiponectin in adipocytes which suppresses insulin resistance [ [67](#B67-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Nonetheless, PPAR rceptors are expressed on bone-marrow-pluripotent mesenchymal stem cells differentiating into adipocytes or osteoblasts, and their stimulation may lead to improved adipocyte differentiation instead of osteoblast differentiation. PPAR stimulation also supports osteoclast development. As a result, bone loss is significant after one year of treatment with a higher risk of fractures. These conditions are manifested by a reduced osteoblast number, decreased blood vessel formation, and increased number of adipocytes at the healing site [ [57](#B57-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [68](#B68-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Furthermore, another well-known adverse impact is weight gain. Supposedly, weight gain may be caused by disturbances in adipose tissue distribution. Other side effects include fluid retention, oedema, anaemia, and the risk of cardiac failure. In patients treated with these medications, upper respiratory tract infections, sinusitis, and headaches can also be diagnosed [ [61](#B61-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [64](#B64-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. 3.1.2. Insulin Secretagogues [68](#B68-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [69](#B69-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [70](#B70-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The first phase of the insulin response is reduced and is partly responsible for the postprandial adjustment of plasma glucose in T2DM. After a prolonged duration of the disease, the second phase of the insulin response is reduced [ [69](#B69-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Insulin secretagogues include sulphonylureas and meglitinides. first includes tolbutamide, tolazamide, chlorpropamide, and acetohexamide; the second consists of glyburide (also known as glibenclamide), glipizide, and gliclazide; and the third generation consists of glimepiride. These generations have the same mechanism of action; however, the second and third generations greatly support the loss of weight [ [72](#B72-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [73](#B73-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The mechanism of sulphonylureas action relies on their binding to the transmembrane sulphonylurea receptor (SUR-1), a regulatory subunit of ATP-sensitive K+ channels, and mediates their closing leading to a release of pre-formed insulin. The main side effect of this process includes hypoglycaemia [ [68](#B68-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The risk of hypoglycaemia is higher in elderly people, and people with multiple medications [ [74](#B74-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], impaired renal functions [ [75](#B75-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], and liver disease. Other side effects include weight gain (1-4 kg over 6 months), skin reactions, acute porphyria and, rarely, hyponatraemia [ [68](#B68-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The treatment with sulphonylureas can be critical for patients with cardiovascular disease [ [76](#B76-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Hypoglycaemia is also associated with increased fracture development. On the contrary, sulphonylureas appear to have a beneficial or neutral impact on diabetic bone disorder [ [77](#B77-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Meglitinides [78](#B78-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Nateglinide, repaglinide, and mitiglinide are members of this group [ [79](#B79-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. They have a different chemical structure: nateglinide is an amino acid derivate, repaglinide is a carbamoyl methyl benzoic acid derivative, and mitiglinide is a derivative of benzylsuccinic acid propionate dihydrate [ [80](#B80-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Glinides have a fast onset but a short duration of action. As sulphonylureas, they bind to the pancreatic -cell receptor and regulate the closure of K+ channels in these cells [ [78](#B78-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [81](#B81-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. However, in contrast with sulphonylureas, their association to the sulphonylurea receptor 1 binding site is weaker and their dissociation from this receptor is faster [ [82](#B82-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Glinides are also called "short-acting type insulin secretagogues", and they primarily control postprandial blood glucose level [ [79](#B79-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] by increasing insulin secretion [ [78](#B78-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Their application may likely lead to elevated glucagon secretion [ [83](#B83-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Treatment with meglitinides is consistent with weight gain similar to sulphonylureas therapy. The advantage of these medications (in contrast to sulphonylureas) is the decreased percentage of hypoglycaemia events thanks to their weaker binding strength [ [81](#B81-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [84](#B84-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. These drugs may also be critical in patients with cardiovascular disease, although their potential side effects are minor due to their shorter half-lives [ [83](#B83-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The other adverse impacts involve rhinitis and bronchitis [ [80](#B80-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. No beneficial or negative effects of meglitinides application have been reported on diabetic bone structure so far [ [85](#B85-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. 3.1.3. decay of disaccharides and oligosaccharides, and the absorption of glucose monomers in the small intestine [ [88](#B88-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors have a high affinity for alpha-glucosidases. Due to their nitrogen content, they are able to block enzymatic reactions [ [89](#B89-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. They reduce the upper alpha-glucosidases, leading to a delay in the absorption of carbohydrates in the small intestine. As a result, postprandial blood glucose and insulin levels are reduced [ [90](#B90-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [91](#B91-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Lower postprandial glucose concentration is associated with improved -cells function. Additionally, alpha-glucosidase inhibitors stimulate GLP-1 release from the gut [ [85](#B85-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. They influence body weight gain, support insulin sensitivity, adjust blood pressure, protect against heart disease, and reduce hypertriglyceridaemia. On the contrary, they do not affect diabetic bone disorder. Some undesirable impacts on intestinal disturbances such as vomiting, flatulence, diarrhoea, headache, and insomnia, have been incretin-based antidiabetic drugs have beneficial effects on diabetic bone structure. They inhibit bone resorption and have anabolic properties [ [77](#B77-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The action of incretins can be influenced by several nutrients, mainly glucose and carbohydrates [ [95](#B95-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Their concentrations are small during fasting, but they increase rapidly after food ingestion. From understanding the mechanism of incretin system action, a new class of drugs has been found—incretin mimetics. Current pancreatic islets, kidney, lungs, heart, and nervous system. After the binding of GLP-1 and GLP1-agonists to the receptor, glucose-dependent insulin secretion is induced [ [94](#B94-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. GLP-1R agonists, structurally related to the native gut peptide, are administered by a subcutaneous injection. This group also able to inhibit glucagon secretion and hepatic glucose production, influence - and -cell dysfunction, delay gastric emptying, and induce satiety [ [94](#B94-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [99](#B99-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The decrease of blood glucose, induced by GLP-1 receptor agonists, can be affected by baseline glucose level. For example, in the study of Berra et al. [ [100](#B100-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], patients with high glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) at baseline saw its greatest reduction after 6 months of once-a-week administration of dulaglutide. The low baseline of HbA1c and the short duration of diabetes were important predictors of the achievement of HbA1c 7.0%. The percentage of subjects with HbA1c 7.0% increased from 7.2% at baseline to 52.7% after 6 months in this study. According to the recent update of guideline ESC-EASD [ [101](#B101-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], treatment with GLP-1 receptor agonists is recommended as the first option in diabetic patients, particularly in those at risk of cardiovascular disease, because of an important effect on both primary and secondary prevention of ischemic disease. On the other hand, GLP-1 receptor agonists can cause transient gastrointestinal problems (e.g., nausea and diarrhoea), local irritation, local nodule formation (caused by the injection), and pancreatitis [ [102](#B102-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], and their use further poses a risk to patients with renal impairment or end-stage renal disease [ [97](#B97-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. that influence glucose-dependent insulin secretion, cause a delay in gastric emptying, increase levels of active GLP-1, decrease levels of postprandial glucagon, and reduce food intake [ [105](#B105-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [106](#B106-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [107](#B107-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. They mimic many of the actions of GLP-1, including the preservation of -cell mass [ [108](#B108-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Their other benefits incorporate anti-inflammatory, cardiovascular protective, and potential immunomodulatory effects [ [104](#B104-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. They do not cause weight gain, hypoglycaemia, and only a few gastrointestinal side effects have been reported. However, their long-term administration may lead to a risk of new heart failure and/or abnormalities in cardiac remodelling in patients with established heart failure [ [103](#B103-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [109](#B109-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. 3.1.5. SGLT2 Inhibitors [110](#B110-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In general, all filtered glucose undergoes reabsorption in the kidney tubules and more than 90% of glucose is reabsorbed by SGLT2. Under hyperglycaemic conditions, SGLT2 becomes overexpressed leading to increased reabsorption. Inhibitors of SGLT2 block the reabsorption process, resulting in an increase in urinary glucose excretion [ [111](#B111-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Currently used SGLT2 inhibitors are analogues of phlorizin, a natural compound isolated from the bark of apple trees [ [112](#B112-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Four phlorizin-based SGLT2 inhibitors are commercially available in the U.S. and Europe [ [45](#B45-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [111](#B111-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]: canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, empagliflozin, and ertugliflozin. In addition, tofogliflozin and luseogliflozin have been approved in Japan. These drugs not only control blood glucose levels but also have the potential to improve cardiovascular system function, reduce kidney disorders, and normalize the lipid profile. They could be used either as monotherapy or in combination with other antidiabetic agents (especially with metformin) in T2DM patients [ [113](#B113-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. However, some important side effects have been reported with phlorizin-derived SGLT2 inhibitors, including urinary and genital infections, ketoacidosis, and even an increased risk of bladder cancer (dapagliflozin), or amputation and bone fractures (canagliflozin) [ [111](#B111-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. 3.2. Natural Therapeutic Products for the Treatment of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus [114](#B114-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Currently, there are constant changes in food production and consumption [ [34](#B34-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Natural health products are defined as vitamins, minerals, herbs, spices, and homeopathic and traditional medicines (e.g., Chinese medicines, probiotics, and other products like amino acids and essential fatty acids) [ [115](#B115-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [116](#B116-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Herbal medicine belongs to the category of alternative medicine. The possibility of improving glycaemic control without pharmaceutical drugs or insulin injections is attractive to humans. Natural therapeutic products for the treatment of T2DM focus on main pathophysiological mechanisms, identical to those of pharmaceutical agents, e.g., regulation of insulin secretion, enhancement of insulin resistance, and insulin sensitivity [ [117](#B117-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [118](#B118-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. They also influence adverse concentrations of blood lipids, focusing on achieving the suitable energy to balance weight and diabetic complications, and improve health conditions [ [119](#B119-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. While the prolonged administration of pharmaceutical drugs may cause many side effects, herbal medicines are non-toxic with a mild action and a minimal risk of contraindications or harmful impacts [ [120](#B120-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [121](#B121-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Some side effects are still unknown due to undiscovered metabolites that are the result of microbial degradation in the human body [ [122](#B122-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Studies and experiments are usually short-term and involve a small sample size. At the present moment, our knowledge of the efficacy and safety of natural health products is lower than that of pharmaceutical products [ [116](#B116-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Another disadvantage of the use of natural compounds is that they are less effective [ [115](#B115-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], so they are recommended in the pre-diabetic stage, in the early stage of T2DM and in combination with pharmaceutical drugs [ [123](#B123-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In this review, natural health substances are divided into following categories: non-flavonoid and plant fruits, vegetables and other products (e.g., garlic, green tea, blackcurrant, rowanberry, bilberry, strawberry, Cornelian cherry, olive oil, sesame oil, and carrot). Although flavonoids belong to polyphenols, we list them as a separate category due to their high importance in the treatment of T2DM. [Figure 3](#pharmaceuticals-14-00806-f003)illustrates chemical structures of selected natural compounds. Their known effects and mechanisms of action are listed in [Table 1](#pharmaceuticals-14-00806-t001). 3.2.1. Polyphenols [167](#B167-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Tijjani et polyphenols: phenolics, stilbenes, flavonoids, tannins, and lignans. They affect some metabolic processes of the cell, e.g., blocking cell apoptosis and reducing enzymes such as lipoxygenase and telomerase [ [169](#B169-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Their consumption can contribute to the enhanced protection against various diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular disorder, osteoporosis, and neurodegenerative damage [ [167](#B167-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. T2DM is one of the most studied diseases that can be affected by the activity of polyphenols [ [129](#B129-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. From the group of non-flavonoid polyphenols, resveratrol, curcumin, tannins, with plant-derived stilbene with anti-inflammatory, anti-carcinogenic, and with the ability to support endothelial cell function. It can improve insulin sensitivity in patients with T2DM, diet-induced obese mice and rats, resistance in T2DM. In addition, resveratrol has antioxidant properties and can protect -cells from oxidative stress. It also reduces the risk of diabetic neuropathy [ [125](#B125-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [126](#B126-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] and interacts with the PPAR receptor [ [127](#B127-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Another beneficial effect of resveratrol is the reduction of hyperlipidaemia and dyslipidaemia [ [126](#B126-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [170](#B170-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Bo et al. [ [171](#B171-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] reveal its ability to prevent bone loss in patients with T2DM. Grapes, berries, and peanuts are important sources of [125](#B125-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Curcumin [172](#B172-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [173](#B173-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. sensitivity [ [128](#B128-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The mechanism of curcumin action is possible via the inhibition of lipid peroxidation, NF-B activation, and the reduction of inflammatory cytokine levels. These conditions support pancreatic cell viability [ [129](#B129-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [174](#B174-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Curcumin is also able to inhibit the activity of alpha-amylase and alpha-glucosidase leading to the delayed absorption of carbohydrates or nutrients in the small intestine [ [43](#B43-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Moreover, a study by He et al. [ [175](#B175-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] revealed its potential use for bone regeneration at high glucose concentrations. On the other hand, this natural supplement has poor bioavailability [ [173](#B173-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Tannins [176](#B176-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. They can be divided into hydrolyzable and condensed tannins. Condensed tannins are also called proanthocyanidins. Tannins can provide protection against degenerative diseases. They have high antioxidant [ [177](#B177-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], anti-inflammatory and They are able to reduce postprandial hyperglycaemia and prevent or delay glucose absorption by inhibiting alpha-glucosidase activities. Other useful characteristics include adipocyte inhibition, an insulin-like effect, glucose transport stimulation, insulin receptor phosphorylation, and GLUT 4 translocation [ [130](#B130-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [131](#B131-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In addition, they reduce the formation and accumulation of AGEs, which are responsible for the development of chronic diabetic complications [ [132](#B132-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. These polyphenolic compounds can also prevent cardiovascular damage [ [182](#B182-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The sources of tannins are cereals, legumes, nuts, grapes, apricots, barley, peaches, dried fruits, mint, basil, rosemary, pomegranate, strawberries, rice, and oats. They can also be found in beverages such as green tea, black tea, wine, fruit juice, beer, and coffee [ [132](#B132-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [176](#B176-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Lignans [183](#B183-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), major lignan found mainly in flaxseed. Flaxseed consumption has shown to decrease blood glucose and lipid levels, delay postprandial glucose absorption, and reduce inflammation and oxidative stress in patients with pre-diabetes [ [133](#B133-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In obese mice, flaxseed SDG also lowers blood glucose, insulin, free fatty acids, and improves oral glucose tolerance and insulin signalling [ [134](#B134-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. According to Draganescu et al. [ [136](#B136-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] and Prasad [ [135](#B135-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], both flaxseed extract and SDG isolated from flaxseed delay the development of T2DM in diabetic rats. Lignans can mediate their effects by a variety of mechanisms, including the modulation of pancreatic insulin and alpha-amylase secretion, increasing insulin sensitivity, and improving their antioxidative capacity. Wang et al. [ [134](#B134-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] demonstrated the ability of flaxseed SDG to increase the expression of GLUT4 proteins in the muscle tissue. Lignans may also act via estrogen receptor-mediated mechanisms [ [185](#B185-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Other sources of lignans are foods rich in fibre, such as whole grains, legumes, several beverages (e.g., coffee and wine), oilseeds, fruits, and vegetables [ [183](#B183-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [186](#B186-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. 3.2.2. Flavonoids [118](#B118-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [122](#B122-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In vitro and animal model studies show their ability to prevent diabetes and its subsequent complications. They have positive effects on carbohydrate and lipid metabolisms, and suppress hepatic enzyme activities [ [187](#B187-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [188](#B188-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. They receive a lot of attention due to their structural diversity, abundance in nature, and strong pharmacological activity with low adverse reactions [ [141](#B141-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In this review, we characterize anthocyanins, epigallocatechin gallate, quercetin, Anthocyanins [189](#B189-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Generally, anthocyanins have significant antioxidant activities and are therefore used for the treatment of chronic and degenerative diseases such as diabetes, and cardiovascular and neurodegenerative disorders. Their antidiabetic properties are associated with lowering diastolic blood pressure and levels of triglycerides [ [190](#B190-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] and serum LDL cholesterol, as well as increasing HDL cholesterol concentrations [ [191](#B191-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Other beneficial effects include the prevention of free radical production and lipid peroxidation, improved insulin secretion and insulin resistance, and the inhibition of alpha-glucosidase activity [ [137](#B137-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. However, data from studies with a large number of subjects and from research with isolated compounds, including anthocyanins, are still missing [ [190](#B190-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Significant sources of anthocyanins berries (e.g., blackberries, bilberries, elderberries, Gallate [138](#B138-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. anti-inflammatory features, and increases glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, as well as increasing the number and size of pancreatic islets [ [129](#B129-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [140](#B140-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [192](#B192-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. On the other hand, the negative effects of epigallocatechin gallate on -cells were revealed in the study by Yun et al. [ [193](#B193-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], where alloxan-induced diabetic rats showed an impaired islet cell mass loss and insulin immunoreactivity in -cells. This conflict study points to the need for further research. Quercetin [194](#B194-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. It reduces the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), inhibits lipid peroxidation, increases plasma levels of adiponectin and HDL cholesterol. In addition, it has strong antidiabetic properties. It can enhance glucose uptake by a MAPK insulin-dependent mechanism and increase the phosphorylation of PI3K/Akt signalling pathways. This condition leads to the translocation of the glucose transporter 4 and downregulation of the activity of gluconeogenesis enzymes in the liver [ [141](#B141-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [142](#B142-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Quercetin also interacts with the PPAR receptor [ [127](#B127-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Its consumption improves the action of -cells [ [143](#B143-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] and proliferation, and inhibits alpha-glucosidase and alpha-amylase activities. Quercetin may improve diabetic bone disorder in patients with T2DM. It increases serum levels of calcium (Ca), vitamin D, and osteocalcin which improve bone mineralization. Its main disadvantage is the low bioavailability. Quercetin can be found in onions, apples, berries, many nuts, seeds, barks, flowers, tea, brassica vegetables, and leaves [ [141](#B141-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [195](#B195-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. [196](#B196-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Moreover, the antihyperlipidaemic and antihyperglycaemic activities of naringin have also been revealed. It improves insulin signalling [ [144](#B144-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] and reduces blood glucose and cholesterol levels in experimental animals and patients with T2DM. The mechanism of its action is possible through the upregulation of PPAR (it improves pancreatic -cells cell dysfunction), and the upregulation of 5 AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) in skeletal muscle cells (it increases glucose uptake). Furthermore, naringin can inhibit serum DPP-4 levels, enhance hepatic glycolysis and glycogen levels, and decrease hepatic gluconeogenesis. It can also improve mitochondrial dysfunction in the liver, and vascular dysfunction in obese Wistar rats [ [129](#B129-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [145](#B145-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [146](#B146-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The study by Liu et al. [ [197](#B197-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] discovered the potential of naringenin (part of naringin) in the prevention of bone damage by reduced overactivated bone resorption under antidiabetic and anti-inflammatory properties include lowering blood glucose levels, modulating insulin secretion, improving dyslipidaemia conditions, inhibiting AGEs formation, and positively influencing IRS-2/PI3K/Akt/GSK-3 signalling pathways [ [147](#B147-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Rutin may be found in fruits and fruit rinds, especially in citrus fruits, e.g., oranges, grapefruits, lemons, and limes. However, it can also occur in other food, such as buckwheat seeds [ [199](#B199-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], onions, apples, tea, and red wine [ [198](#B198-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Kaempferol [201](#B201-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In addition, it is an important regulator of lipid metabolism. It lowers plasma lipid levels, hepatic triglyceride and cholesterol levels, and reduces the accumulation of hepatic lipid droplets [ [202](#B202-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The antidiabetic activities of kaempferol are associated with the prevention of hyperglycaemia development, the suppression of hepatic gluconeogenesis through the reduction of pyruvate carboxylase activity [ [148](#B148-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Kaempferol may also improve insulin sensitivity by inhibiting pro-inflammatory cytokines, leading to reduced inflammatory responses and hepatic inflammatory lesions [ [149](#B149-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Kaempferol is presented in tea, cruciferous vegetables, grapefruit, Gingko biloba, and some edible berries [ [201](#B201-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. 3.2.3. Plant Fruits, Vegetables and Other Products [5](#B5-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In this review, selected plant fruits, vegetables and other products containing bioactive substances with demonstrable beneficial effects are listed below. Garlic [150](#B150-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [151](#B151-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. On the contrary, studies demonstrating its hypoglycaemic impacts on humans are contradictory. The meta-analysis of Hou et al. [ [152](#B152-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] revealed a reduced postprandial blood glucose level in humans consuming garlic, while that of Emami et al. [ [151](#B151-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] revealed opposite findings. The potential side effects of consuming garlic include allergic contact dermatitis, allergic conjunctivitis, rhinitis, bloating, headache, dizziness, and profuse sweating [ [150](#B150-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Green Tea [154](#B154-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The results indicate that the antidiabetic properties of green tea drinking are not clear. According to Sharma et al. [ [153](#B153-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], green tea consumption can increase insulin secretion, lower blood glucose levels, improve insulin resistance, and reduce diabetic complications. These assumptions are supported by the study of Liu et al. [ [154](#B154-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], who detected decreased glucose concentrations and increased insulin binding. Some studies have also demonstrated the ability of green tea to reduce blood pressure, LDL cholesterol, oxidative stress, and chronic inflammation [ [203](#B203-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In contrast, several studies have found no significant effect of drinking green tea on glucose control [ [204](#B204-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [205](#B205-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Green tea has been shown to reduce bone resorption markers and to positively affect bone turnover in patients with T2DM [ [206](#B206-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Blackcurrant [43](#B43-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [155](#B155-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [156](#B156-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Moreover, blackcurrants have a phytoestrogenic activity and can positively influence bone structure [ [207](#B207-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], which could also indicate its beneficial effect on diabetic bone damage. Rowanberry [208](#B208-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Like blackcurrants, rowanberries can also inhibit alpha-glucosidase activity, delay the absorption of carbohydrates in the small intestine, and potentiate the impact of acarbose [ [43](#B43-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [157](#B157-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The study by Grussu et al. [ [158](#B158-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)] demonstrated their ability to inhibit alpha-amylase in vitro. Because acarbose has adverse side effects, supplementation with rowanberries may be an equivalent compensation, but further investigation is needed. Bilberry [160](#B160-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [209](#B209-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [210](#B210-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. According to Güder et al. consumption of bilberries can reduce alpha-amylase and alpha-glucosidase activities due to their high content of anthocyanins. Bilberry extract significantly decreases hyperglycaemia, and has a positive effect on weight gain in ZDF rats. Decreased glucose levels and weight loss were also determined in streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic rats supplemented with bilberry leaf extract [ [160](#B160-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Strawberry [128](#B128-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [211](#B211-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Olive Oil [220](#B220-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)], and oleic acids. Its extra-virgin form is used as a herbal remedy in the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases, diabetes mellitus, obesity, atherosclerosis, cardiovascular disorder, metabolic syndrome, and certain forms of cancer. It is also used as a low-fat diet in the nutritional therapy of T2DM [ [221](#B221-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The study by Rajput et al. Sesame Oil [165](#B165-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [224](#B224-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [225](#B225-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The study by Ramesh et al. Carrot [226](#B226-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [227](#B227-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The study by Kumar et al. Combination Therapy [48](#B48-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [81](#B81-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. The first choice of therapy is usually metformin, which is replaced by sulphonylureas in case of metformin contraindications and/or unsuccessful monotherapy. Thiazolidinediones are used when certain contraindications to metformin have been reported. They can also be used simultaneously with metformin. Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors are recommended as an alternative glucose-lowering therapy in patients who are unable to use other pharmaceutical drugs [ [229](#B229-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [230](#B230-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Meglitinides can be administered separetely or in combination with metformin [ [78](#B78-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. DPP-4 inhibitors are used both as monotherapy simultaneously with metformin, sulphonylureas, or thiazolidinediones [ [231](#B231-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. Prescribing an appropriate combination of medications requires knowledge of many classes of drugs, information on individual agents, and knowledge of important differences between drugs in each class. What is particularly promising are the newest classes of drugs, based on GLP-1R agonists and SGLT2 inhibitors, which currently have a fundamental role in cardiovascular and renal risk reduction in patients with T2DM. Recent studies have shown that even combination therapy with these two classes may produce additive cardiovascular and renoprotective benefits [ [232](#B232-pharmaceuticals-14-00806), [233](#B233-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. SGLT2 Inhibitors with Natural Products [242](#B242-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. 4. Conclusions [248](#B248-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In addition, the beneficial effects of some natural substances have been revealed in in vitro studies but have not been validated in in vivo studies. Most natural compounds with antidiabetic properties have not been clinically tested, and if so, clinical studies often include a limited number of individuals or do not consider the different characteristics of patients with T2DM. Further studies are also needed to reveal the cellular and molecular mechanisms of action of natural compounds, as well as their combinations with current pharmaceutical drugs. In particular, the potential chemical interactions of natural substances with other synthetic products should be carefully considered. For example, plants containing caffeine can interfere with sedative and adrenergic drugs, and garlic can interact with anticoagulants. There may be a potential interaction between dual-acting medicinal products and drugs. An example is olive leaves where their use to improve diabetes can lead to a hypotensive crisis [ [249](#B249-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)]. In addition, various herbal products have antidiabetic effects potentially mediated by the modulation of gut microbiota, which is another promising area of the research [ [250](#B250-pharmaceuticals-14-00806)].
